moat: ditch dug as a fortification and usually filled with water
engrossed: giving or marked by complete attention to
reticent: reluctant to draw attention to yourself
pusillanimous: lacking in courage, strength, and resolution
inimical: tending to obstruct or cause harm
scrupulous: characterized by extreme care and great effort
pellucid: transmitting light; able to be seen through with clarity
auspicious: indicating favorable circumstances and good luck
adulterate: make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance
chicanery: the use of tricks to deceive someone
orthodox: adhering to what is commonly accepted
esoteric: understandable only by an enlightened inner circle
innocuous: not injurious to physical or mental health
sporadic: recurring in scattered or unpredictable instances
pedant: a person who pays too much attention to formal rules
obsequious: attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery
misanthrope: someone who dislikes people in general
commensurate: corresponding in size or degree or extent
rebound: spring back; spring away from an impact
precursor: something indicating the approach of something or someone
repudiate: refuse to acknowledge, ratify, or recognize as valid
reconvene: meet or cause to meet again
crass: so unrefined as to be offensive or insensitive
impassive: having or revealing little emotion or sensibility
discerning: having or revealing keen insight and good judgment
permeable: allowing fluids or gases to pass or diffuse through
inundate: fill or cover completely, usually with water
compliant: disposed to act in accordance with someone's wishes
buttress: a support usually of stone or brick
pungent: strong and sharp to the sense of taste or smell
derivative: a compound obtained from another compound
impervious: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected
capricious: determined by chance or impulse rather than by necessity
trite: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
placate: cause to be more favorably inclined
doctrinaire: a stubborn person of arbitrary or arrogant opinions
apostasy: rejection of religious beliefs, political party, or cause
feign: make believe with the intent to deceive
eclectic: selecting what seems best of various styles or ideas
ossified: set in a rigidly conventional pattern of behavior or beliefs
qualm: uneasiness about the fitness of an action
spendthrift: someone who spends money freely or wastefully
perfunctory: hasty and without attention to detail; not thorough
complaisant: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others
strut: walk with a lofty proud gait
penury: a state of extreme poverty or destitution
vista: the visual percept of a region
fledgling: young bird that has just become capable of flying
refulgence: the quality of being bright and sending out rays of light
filibuster: a tactic for delaying legislation by making long speeches
inure: cause to accept or become hardened to
effrontery: audacious behavior that you have no right to
machinist: a craftsman skilled in operating machine tools
impersonate: pretend to be someone you are not
superfluous: more than is needed, desired, or required
parody: a composition that imitates or misrepresents a style
ostensible: appearing as such but not necessarily so
sibilant: of speech sounds forcing air through a constricted passage
consternate: fill with confusion, dismay, or dread
exculpate: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges
arduous: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion
axiom: a proposition that is not susceptible of proof or disproof
